9 October 2023, 1530 - 1630 hrs

(In person)

Internal Team Meeting

  1. Decide on theme and analysis plan

  2. List down questions we have for prof

  3. Set and book consultation with Prof

  4. To do by next meeting

  5. AOM
  1. Theme and analysis plan:

For Theme 1

  • Looks more interesting but to check with Prof about our analysis plan to see feasibility of plan and if our understanding of the Theme is correct

  • Analysis:

    • Choose two dates for comparison

    • Data compilation

  • Questions

    • How to choose the two dates to compare the land use/land cover? Should we research the optimal dates? Is there a “best practice” method of choosing the two dates for comparison?

    • How can we do the comparison

      • Like something similar to NDVI for different kinds of land use.

      • Or some classification tool for satellite data

    • Should we take into account the different types of flooding and the land use?

      • Eg: pluvial and fluvial flooding and land use

For Theme 2

  • Somewhat like the Childcare Center accessibility analysis

  • Analysis:

    • Approach would be like the childcare accessibility for Punggol area

    • Finding out distance between residential areas and medical and evacuation areas

For Theme 3

  • GIS and remote sensing data → remote sensing data aspect would be the satellite images, QGIS analysis comes in for recovery planning, distance to evacuation centres

  • Analysis:

    • Possible dataset: https://data.humdata.org/dataset/buildings-footprint-floods-derna-libya

  • Question:

    • What kind of loss (areas impacted more by flood?)

Is the data on flood impact on buildings relevant to this theme?

Some reading and literature review of the application
13 October 2023, 0900 - 0930 hrs (Zoom) Consultation with Prof

Prof’s explanation for Theme 1:

This week hands on not enough

  • Extract data

  • Image enhancement

  • Derive composite image

  • Need also next week lesson

Idea is - apply appropriate methods to do land classification

  • When doing classification - label to different land cover type

    • Refer to hands on for next week - do sampling

      • refer to the carte composite layer, identify to confirm the land use

      • Use it as training data to classify entire image

    • Refer to colour composite map - true and false (main source)

      • get different land cover types with various colour composite maps

      • Use other resources - higher res data/ open street map

On choosing the different dates

  • Before and after the flood
    • As close as possible to the event

On different types of flooding

  • Should be able to detect using satellite imagery

  • This particular flooding - cause by 2 factors

    • Natural - big storm

      • But there is a dam there to regulate the area, but 2 of the dam collapsed, cannot regulate water

    • Dam collapse

Use case for this kind of analysis?

  • Quantify and delineate extend of flood and dam failure from change detection

    • How far the flood affect the area - not the entire city

    • Extent of the impact is also different

      • Eg: location near rivers and near dams - greater impact as compared to those further

    • Know the infrastructure affected - roads, buildings, etc.

    • Assess level of damages - use this as a reference for mitigation and prevention

Prof’s explanation for Theme 3:

What kind of loss (areas impacted more by flood?)

  • Referring to the data sources provided:

    • Combine the UN libya data with satellite data

      • See how many facilities that can still be accessed? (E.g: healthcare facilities, roads, etc)

  • All kinds of losses

    • Quantify the type of losses

    • Eg: close to 500 km of roads network severely affected

      • Help engineers/ city council to estimate repair needed (the extent)

Is the data on flood impact on buildings relevant to this theme?

  • After the data is combined - eg financial services with satellite

    • Detect how financial services are affected

A question raised on the difference between Theme 1 and 3:

  • 1: focus on satellite imagery, classification and machine learning to see difference in change detection

    • Make use of image detection to see changes.

  • 3: one change detection to delineate flood loss

    • More fine grained to see how the flood has affected.

    • More on impact assessments

Prof’s response to General Questions:

Question: Is there a format for the meeting minutes?

  • Current one is good enough

  • Content more important - document discussion in greater detail

    • Who asked what and rationale for asking

Question: Under methodology what is required (General walkthrough or step by step)?

  • Some have high level discussion - with separate tab/ word doc to describe steps (like take home exercise)

  • Project - leeway to be creative - learning experience from take home

  • Important to provide detail and reproducible documentation of process gone through

    • People can reproduce
 Select Theme for Analysis and draft out analysis plan

19 October 2023, 0900 - 0930 hrs (Zoom)

Consultation with Prof. Kam

  1. Ask Prof. Kam questions

Question on the suitability of using data on 22 September for the “after” comparison, instead of data from just after the flood, due to lack of clear data:

  • To check data for 12 and 13 September on Sentinel (should not have high cloud cover)

How much test data is typically appropriate? How to decide?

  • Has more to do with the spread (should get a variety for each class)

  • For each land cover type (class, not meta class), at least 30 pixels (in total)

Pros and cons of grouping in the same meta class/ separate?

  • Can group classes under one meta class

Any recommendations for other classification tools to use?

  • Those shared in class should be good enough

  • Usually GIS community uses statistical methods but are moving towards ML techniques

  • Usually use maximum likelihood under statistical methods

  • SCP only provides random forest in terms of ML techniques

  • Can search for remote sensing under plugins and we will see a list

  • Can explore Orfeo

On choosing the training data/ testing data - which layer (TCC/ FCC) to use?

  • Training data should be different before and after

  • Different samples from same location but categorised to different land use types

  • For after flood: severely damaged, moderately damaged, not damaged

    • Use humanitarian data source (ground truth) to find

How to determine the extent of the flood

  • Depends on the classification map

Purpose of PCA

  • A form of transformation such that the data is not correlated

  • Used to deal with highly correlated data (e.g. infrared and red light when there is high vegetation)

  • Maximum likelihood method isn’t suitable when dealing with highly correlated data

 Search again for suitable post flood data
21 October 2023, 1500 - 1700 hrs (In person)

Internal Team Meeting

Agenda

  1. Decide on classification Tools and algorithms to explore

  2. Go through general steps for analysis (the step by step guide)

  3. Update classes

  1. Other than SCP for maximum likelihood and minimum distance, look into Dzetsaka Plugin

    • Reason: Dzetsaka provides more options for different algorithms to classify raster data (SVM, Random Forest, KNN, Gaussian Mixture Model)

  2. For both Pre and Post floods raster layers:

Select classes - same for training and testing

Training

  • Select areas, add training samples for each land cover type

  • Check ROI signature

  • Run SCP Classification on 2 Algorithm: Minimum Distance and Maximum Likelihood

  • Run Random forest classification with Dzetsaka

Testing

  • Add testing samples for each land cover type

  • Calculate accuracy for the different algorithms using the same test samples in previous step - with SCP

Select better Algorithm

Final evaluation of classification model

  1. Updated classes

  • Built-up area

  • Bare land

  • Impervious surfaces

  • Water body

  • Vegetation

  • Cloud

  • Cloud shadow

Added new classes for cloud and cloud shadow to account for the cloud cover and cloud shadow present in post flood dataset

Perform Classification on Pre-Flood and Post-Flood raster data using SCP and other tools

To share classification results with each other

Decide on classification tool/ plugin to use

30 October 2023, 1630 - 1700 hrs

(Zoom)

Consultation with Prof. Kam

  1. Ask about addressing Cloud Cover for Geoeye data

  2. Ask about Bands used for colour composite maps (Sentinel data and Geoeye)

  3. Ask about inability to see spectral signature plot after selecting ROIs

Addressing Cloud Cover for GeoEye data:

  • Try Random Forest for Geoeye data classification if Max Likelihood is not working

  • SCP Cloud Masking should work for all data types

  • Check Spectral Plot to see min and max values for each Band > Band 4 seems to have no difference between classes, so remove it

    • To research how to (currently getting error message: Unable to remove bands in a multiband image)

  • To note that the resolution is different for Sentinel and GeoEye satellite data so it might affect the number of pixels classified as a class

Bands used for colour composite maps:

  • Brought up False Colour Composite issue when using bands 4-3-2 for False

    • Prof. Kam’s response: Not an issue! It really looks like that due to different land cover in Derna

  • Prof. Kam brought up observation that GeoEye Band 4 is noise

    • Tried removing Band 4 but unable to remove

Inability to see spectral signature plots after digitising ROIs:

  • Wei Ni not able to see signature plot as the type is ROI instead of R&S in her ROI Signature list

    • Prof. Kam suspects that there is error with one band

    • Suggested to split up bands and bring bands in one by one

      • QGIS has function to split multiband into single band

Research how to split multiband images into individual bands

Remove band 4 / any bands without different min and max between bands

Perform classification
3 November 2023 No meeting - decisions made offline

  • Changed Pre-Flood and Post-Flood Raster data source to Maxar

    • This is due to issues with Band 4 of the original GeoEye data from OpenArialMap and because Maxar provides raster maps for both Pre-Flood and Post-Flood, allowing us to standardise the resolution of the maps used for Land Cover Change Detection
 Perform Classification using data from Maxar

6 November 2023,

1600 - 1730 hrs

(In person)

Internal Team Meeting

  1. Perform Land use Change Detection using SCP

  2. Draw insights from Land use Change Detection
  • Conducted land use change detection on Xin Yi’s laptop for the pre and post flood classification layer with the SCP plugin.
  • After the analysis is conducted, decided to focus on changes to two land cover types of interest for Land Cover Change Detection:
    • Bare land
    • Water body
    • This is because land use changes to bare land and water bodies reflect areas of damage and flooding.

Insights from the land use change detection include:

  • Areas near the dam are more damaged due to greater change to bare land

  • Flooding present near the coast

 Create template for poster on canva
